title-group.article-title: Hyperglycemia in the Newborn—Clinical Guidelines Are Needed but Must Be Based on Correct Reporting of the Data

body.p: The stated objective of the article by Arsenault et al,1 to develop guidelines for the management of glucose control in the neonate receiving parenteral nutrition, is an important one. The evidence base remains unclear, with wide variation in clinical practice, and many clinicians are keen for guidance. However, we are concerned that some of the evidence presented in this article is inaccurate and as such misleading.

First, the phrase “early continuous insulin infusion” is used to describe several studies that have important differences in methodology. The studies by Collins et al2 and Meetze et al3 treated babies once they had become hyperglycemic with insulin to reduce glucose levels and limit hyperglycemia, rather than reducing dextrose infusion rates. In comparison, the 2 studies by Beardsall et al4,5 aimed to start insulin “early,” within 24 hours of birth (supported by 20% dextrose), to prevent hyperglycemia.

Second, the statement that the randomized controlled trial (NIRTURE, with the intervention of early insulin infusion) was “terminated early due to increased incidence of hypoglycemia and mortality” is incorrect. As is clearly stated in the original NEJM article, the study was stopped on the grounds of futility: “Although there was no statistical difference in the prespecified secondary outcome of ultrasound evidence of intracranial disease, the recommendation of the data and safety monitoring committee was based on a combination of futility associated with the primary outcome and concern about potential harm. After this suspension, the trial steering committee recommended that the trial be discontinued on the grounds of futility.”5
